awd_titl_txt: RUI:   Restoration of lead (Pb) contaminated soils through chemically enhanced phytoextraction by switchgrass (Panicum virgatum)
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite great progress in limiting new lead (Pb) sources of emissions, chronic lead hazards remain particularly in urban areas.   In U.S. cities, diffuse lead in soils (lead that has been dispersed in soils from a source such as leaded gasoline combustion exhaust) is a persistent reservoir of lead, contributing to long term chronic exposure. Efforts to develop efficient lead removal techniques have included a number of biological and geochemical manipulations that each, alone, has produced significant incremental improvements. A goal of this project is to combine the individual factors affecting lead uptake to increase the efficiency of lead removal from soils in a common, fast growing model plant (switchgrass). The project researchers are investigating a series of soil amendments, including a fungicide, metal chelator, and plant growth regulator, for improving lead removal from the soil and concentrating it into the above-ground parts of the plant.  The plants could then be removed and disposed of in a safe manner.

Efforts to develop efficient lead phytoremediation techniques have included soil fungicide (benomyl) treatments to down-regulate the metal exclusion actions of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) and the application of lead chelating agents, such as citric acid, in soil to mobilize lead and enhance its uptake to plant biomass. In such cases, however, the phytotoxicity of lead limits plant life and creates a limit on uptake capacity. The project researchers are studying whether phytoextraction of lead can be enhanced further by a coordinated application of foliar iron (Fe), plant growth regulator and exogenous nitric oxide donors. These manipulations may serve to increase the phytoextraction efficiency of the high biomass producing switchgrass (Panicum virgatum). The research team is using state-of-the-art experimental greenhouse facilities at Kennesaw State University, along with contaminated soils sampled from urban Atlanta and a former Superfund site in Cedertown, GA.  Experimental conditions are being systematically varied among soil fungicide, chelate, and foliar application of iron, plant growth regulator and exogenous nitric oxide (NO) donor, singly and in combination, to optimize each and test for synergistic effects. High throughput DNA sequences of AMF assemblages in lead-contaminated and non-contaminated soils will be extracted and analyzed to characterize AMF species composition. The chemical analysis of lead, iron, phosphorous (P), and the full suite of macro- and micro-nutrients are being determined in soil and plant tissue samples. The research project has the potential for contributing to scientific knowledge on phytoremediation while also training undergraduate student researchers in high level research. Results of this project have the potential to dramatically improve phytoextraction rates and guide the development of a soil restoration technique appropriate for technology transfer.

por.por_cntn:
Soil lead (Pb)-contamination is widespread mainly due to anthropogenic sources and poses an environmental hazards and risk to human health.  Lead stored in ambient soils is a persistent reservoir of Pb, contributing to long-term chronic exposure of infants and children.  Soil remediation techniques include phytoextraction to remove contaminants from soil using plants and associated microbes which is beneficial due to low cost and minimal soil disruption.  In this study, we used for phytoextraction of Pb-contaminated soil, the native switchgrass (Panicum virgatum L.), a second-generation bioenergy crop.  Soil containing high level of Pb (5802.5 mg kg-1) was collected from a former Superfund site in Cedartown, GA and used in a series of experiments where switchgrass was grown in a research greenhouse facilities at Kennesaw State University (KSU).  We proposed that phytoextraction of Pb using switchgrass can be enhanced further and through a series of experiments we tested four main hypotheses.

Hypotheses 1) Lead soil contamination will cause a shift in AMF species assemblages on Pb-contaminated soils compared to non Pb-contaminated soils.

DNA from soil and roots were extracted and the 16S ribosomal DNA was put through internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequencing and next generation sequencing (NGS).  Following the NGS, fungal species were identified and separated into operational taxonomic units (OUT’s).  

The AMF communities did not show a significant reduction in total diversity in Cedartown at high soil Pb concentration, however; only two AMF species dominated in the Cedartown soil.  The AMF communities detected were not similar among sites.  The KSU Field Station had a greater number of AMF species (25) detected than the other sites (16 and 14 species for Cedartown and Decatur sites respectively).  In addition, the number of fungal species detected in Cedartown samples had nearly 30% less species detected than Decatur sites and approximately 21% less species detected than the KSU Field Station site.

Hypotheses 2) Multispecies AMF assemblages derived from Pb-contaminated soils will show high efficiency in Pb tolerance and Fe uptake compared to multispecies AMF assemblages from non-contaminated soils.

Switchgrass grown with soil microbes from a highly Pb-contaminated soil and challenged with a high level (8000 mg kg-1) Pb solution in a peat/vermiculite culture had significantly lowest Pb and Fe concentrations in the foliage suggesting that soil microbes adapt to high soil Pb levels by down-regulating metal uptake of plants.  Therefore, adaptation of soil microbes to high levels of Pb soil contamination was rapid and stresses the importance of using locally adapted soil microbes in phytoremediation.  This project yielded new fundamental understanding of the symbiotic relationship between AMF and plants. 

Hypotheses 3) Lead phytoextraction efficiency of switchgrass will be enhanced by separate foliar application of Fe, PGR (BAP) and NO exogenous donor.

Iron (Fe) foliar application on switchgrass resulted in significantly higher dry mass of foliage and significantly lower Pb concentrations in the roots and the foliage.  In addition, plants receiving solution of high levels of nitrogen (N) had the significantly greatest dry mass of the foliage and the highest Pb concentration. 

The combined foliar application of the nitric oxide (NO) exogenous donor SNP (sodium nitroprusside) and GA3 (gibberellic acid) improved phytoextraction efficiency of switchgrass grown in Pb-contaminated soil.

In addition, we examined the exogenous foliar application of the plant growth regulators diethyl aminoethyl hexanoate (DA-6) and salicylic acid (SA).  Foliar application of the plant growth regulator DA-6 resulted in significantly higher Pb concentrations in the foliage of plants compared to control plants.  The DA-6 did not improve plants dry mass.  Foliar application of SA resulted in significantly greater dry mass of the foliage compared to control plants. 

Hypotheses 4) Coordinated chemical application of soil fungicide, chelate and foliar application of plant growth regulator will improve phytoextraction rates of switchgrass to a degree greater than any of these alone.

Phytoextraction efficiency of Pb-contaminated soil is typically enhanced by soil chelation.  The effect of the chelate nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) was more than doubled by a combined application of alkyl polyglucoside (APG: Triton X-100).  Therefore, the use of NTA combined with APG alongside the soil fungicide propiconazole and foliar application of BAP has a great potential in improving phytoextraction efficiencies of switchgrass on Pb-contaminated soils.  Bioengineering of these parameters was further examined.  The application of NTA (10 mM) + APG and foliar application of BAP resulted in the highest mean concentration of 5,942 mg kg-1 Pb; one individual plant in this treatment contained 10,820 mg kg-1 Pb.  This study suggested that the soil application of NTA (10 mM) + APG alongside the soil fungicide propiconazole and foliar application of BAP can provide the tools for a viable technique for phytoremediation of Pb-contaminated soils.  In conclusion, the outcome of this research project has the potential to improve phytoextraction and develop a soil restoration technique appropriate for large-scale application.
